medium_description_en: Estimates risk of rebound hyperbilirubinemia after inpatient phototherapy.
instructions_en: Use only in neonates ≥35 weeks gestational age (GA) treated with first episode inpatient phototherapy.

seo.meta_description_en: The Rebound Hyperbilirubinemia Risk Score estimates the risk of rebound hyperbilirubinemia after inpatient phototherapy.
seo.keywords_en: Rebound Hyperbilirubinemia Risk Score, rebound hyperbilirubinemia, hyperbilirubinemia, hyperbilirubinemia risk score, infant rebound hyperbilirubinemia, hyperbilirubinemia risk, neonatal hyperbilirubinemia

how_to_use.use_case_en:
• Use in neonates ≥35 weeks GA requiring phototherapy to estimate the risk of rebound hyperbilirubinemia prior to discontinuing inpatient phototherapy.

  • Use only in infants with first episode inpatient phototherapy.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Rebound hyperbilirubinemia as defined by the index study is the return of total serum bilirubin (TSB) to or above the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) phototherapy threshold (guidelines) within 72 hours of phototherapy termination.

  • May be less applicable to older infants (≥6 days) and patients with significantly higher relative TSB values at termination of phototherapy.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Clinicians and parents can make more informed decisions about whether the benefit of earlier phototherapy discontinuation outweighs the risk of rebound hyperbilirubinemia (Chang 2017).

next_steps.management_en:
• The calculator does not recommend a definitive risk level at which to discontinue phototherapy.

  • The decision to continue phototherapy should be made after balancing the risks and costs of prolonging treatment against the benefit of reducing the risk of rebound hyperbilirubinemia.

  • In the derivation study, 34% of infants may have been able to discontinue inpatient phototherapy a day earlier with <4% risk of rebound hyperbilirubinemia.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: Ease of follow up TSB testing and hardship of readmission should be considered in the decision to stop or continue phototherapy in infants regardless of risk score.

about.formula_en:
The Rebound Hyperbilirubinemia Risk Score is calculated based on the following inputs:

  • Gestational age (GA) <38 weeks (yes or no).

  • Age at phototherapy initiation, hours.

  • Total serum bilirubin (TSB) at phototherapy termination.

American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) phototherapy threshold is determined as follows:

Age, hours

AAP Threshold, mg/dL

25-48

15 mg/dL

49-72

18 mg/dL

>72

20 mg/dL

Note: formula assumes TSB and AAP threshold units in mg/dL.

Rebound Hyperbilirubinemia Risk Score = 15*(GA <38 weeks) - 7*(age at phototherapy initiation, days) - 4*(AAP threshold - TSB) + 50

about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
The prediction rule was derived from a retrospective cohort study of 7,048 infants treated with first episode inpatient phototherapy before age 14 days in a single integrated health system between 2012-2014 (Chang 2017). The study excluded infants who had ≥2 TSB measurements and infants with conjugated bilirubin level ≥2 mg/dl before or during their first phototherapy admission. Mean age at initiation of phototherapy in the derivation study was 2.3 days; mean age at termination of phototherapy was 3.6 days and mean estimated TSB at termination of phototherapy was 9.8 mg/dL.

Significant predictors of rebound hyperbilirubinemia identified in the study were: gestational age <38 weeks, younger age at phototherapy initiation, and TSB relative to the treatment threshold at phototherapy termination. The rule was internally validated using a split sample validation method. The area under the ROC curve was 0.89 in the derivation data set and 0.88 in the validation data set.

Validation.text: Chou JH. Predictive models for neonatal follow-up serum bilirubin: model development and validation. JMIR Med Inform. 2020;8(10):e21222.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Chang PW, Kuzniewicz MW, McCulloch CE, Newman TB. A clinical prediction rule for rebound hyperbilirubinemia following inpatient phototherapy. Pediatrics. 2017;139(3):e20162896.

Other References.text: Porter ML, Dennis MBL. Hyperbilirubinemia in the term newborn. AFP. 2002;65(4):599.
Chang PW, Newman TB. A simpler prediction rule for rebound hyperbilirubinemia. Pediatrics. 2019;144(1):e20183712.

Clinical Practice Guidelines.text: Kemper AR, Newman TB, Slaughter JL, et al. Clinical practice guideline revision: management of hyperbilirubinemia in the newborn infant 35 or more weeks of gestation. Pediatrics. 2022;150(3):e2022058859.

creator_info.about_en: Pearl W. Chang, MD, is a pediatrics specialist, currently practicing at Seattle Children’s Hospital in Washington. She graduated with honors from Stanford University School of Medicine in 2011. Dr. Chang’s primary research is focused on urinary tract infections and neonatal jaundice.
